stream_context.summary: Kaze begins Course 12 (a Western/cowboy-themed level) with an art-style and layout planning stream: he iterates on building colors/materials, tests skybox and fog, outlines the town→valley→train HQ structure, and defines three small-boss “outlaw capture” missions that end with jailing the bosses. Badub unexpectedly sends a new track that heavily influences the desired atmosphere.
stream_context.significance_reason: This stream locks in the core fantasy and mission structure for the cowboy level (three outlaw bosses, train fast travel, town layout), and it contains key aesthetic/technical decisions (skybox-first realization, fog requiring 2-cycle materials, performance tradeoffs) plus a new Badub song shaping the vibe.

findings.summary: Course 12 is framed as a comedic, exaggerated ‘goofy cowboy town’ level: Kaze explicitly wants an intentionally over-the-top Western stereotype tone (NPCs all saying “howdy partner,” milk-only saloon, wanted posters everywhere) rather than a gritty Red Dead-style desert.

The level’s main gameplay premise is ‘catching outlaws’: three small bosses (each awarding a star) get ‘put in jail’ after being caught, making the jail/sheriff setup the narrative anchor for the course.

Kaze outlines three specific star missions with comedic ‘investigation’ setups: (1) Saloon secret-room shootout vs an outlaw Snuffit, (2) Monty Mole bank robbery solved by following a continuous mole trail to a boss fight, (3) train robbery mystery where “five Goombas in a trench coat” are exposed and then fought as they disperse and shoot cork guns around town.

Macro layout plan: Area 1 is the town, Area 2 is a valley/traversal ‘playground’ area, Area 3 is the train headquarters/gold mine area; two train stations enable fast travel between Area 1 and Area 3, while players can still walk through Area 2 to reach Area 3.

Kaze wants the level to be roleplay-forward immediately: Mario should spawn facing the jail so the player can’t miss the first ‘what to do’ interaction; he actively designs the camera/starting orientation to force early context.

To support N64 rendering/culling, Kaze explores a circular/‘reverse donut’ town wrapped around a central mountain so distant geometry can be occluded; the saloon is planned as a visually central landmark building.

Fog becomes a major aesthetic target but collides with rendering cost: Kaze notes fogging the level implies using 2-cycle materials (a performance hit), referencing prior experience in Oily Boily Bay and weighing whether the visual payoff justifies the loss.
findings.quote: Unfortunately, this means everything is going to be a 2-cycle material… which is really, really bad. We’ve already experienced this in Oily Boily Bay. There might not be anything we can do about it.

findings.summary: Kaze’s art-direction process shifts midstream: after struggling with building colors (‘monocolor’ vs ‘color vomit’), he realizes the sky/skybox choice dramatically changes the scene and should have been established earlier (‘do the sky first’), then iterates on blue vs orange/yellow fog to complement the canyon palette.
findings.quote: This changes the vibe so much… We should have done the sky first.

findings.summary: Badub messages Kaze mid-stream with what appears to be a newly made Course 12 track; Kaze reacts strongly and immediately uses it to reevaluate atmosphere decisions (fog/overall vibe), treating the music as a direction-setting input.

When asked about explaining his toolchain (Blender + Fast64 export to decomp), Kaze says he doesn’t have a public explanation because Nintendo took down his tutorials—implying a loss of documentation and a chilling effect on sharing process openly.

biobak.summary: Biobak suggests looking at an existing ‘cowboy’ reference level (Beyond the Coast / Cowboy Canyon), prompting Kaze to interpret the actionable takeaway as “more saturation,” though Kaze is skeptical of simply turning a saturation knob as a solution.
Biobak separately frames Kaze’s early building tests as resembling Odyssey’s town aesthetic, which Kaze acknowledges as a comparison point while trying to remain ‘Mario-like’ and not overly modern.

badub.summary: Badub sends a fresh Western-themed music track during the stream; Kaze calls it ‘perfect’ for the level and uses it to guide visual atmosphere choices (fog intensity/color, overall mood).

zeina.summary: Zeina briefly appears indirectly (Kaze hears her come home/talking), but no substantive development discussion occurs with her in this transcript.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I want people to look at this and be like, wow, okay, chill out… I want it to be that, but for cowboys. So, a cowboyaboo.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze articulates the core comedic art-direction goal: intentional, self-aware exaggeration of Western tropes rather than realism.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Unfortunately, this means everything is going to be a 2-cycle material… There might not be anything we can do about it. It might just look so good that we have to take the loss.
memorable_quotes.context: A succinct statement of the project’s recurring tension: aesthetics vs N64-era performance constraints.

key_stories.title: Defining the ‘outlaw capture’ mission structure for Course 12
key_stories.summary: Kaze anchors the cowboy level around a sheriff/jail fantasy where Mario acts as the problem-solver for a town overrun by criminals. He develops three star missions as bite-sized ‘cases’ with comedic reveals, creating a cohesive theme without requiring an overarching story-driven level progression.
key_stories.challenge: How to make a Western town feel like a coherent Mario 64 course with distinct objectives, not just a visual theme.
key_stories.process: Kaze proposes a jail-forward intro, outlines three small boss encounters (saloon Snuffit shootout, bank-robbing Monty Mole trail chase, and a ‘five Goombas in a trench coat’ train-robbery boss), and ties each resolution to ‘putting them in jail.’
key_stories.outcome: A clear mission set emerges that can be mapped onto the town layout and NPC dialogue, giving Course 12 a strong identity and repeatable objective pattern.

key_stories.title: Skybox-first realization while searching for a building palette
key_stories.summary: While iterating on wooden building colors, Kaze can’t get the scene to ‘pop’ without becoming monotone or garishly saturated. He discovers that changing the skybox/lighting direction shifts the entire feel of the level, reframing how he should choose building colors.
key_stories.challenge: Finding a color palette that reads as fun and ‘goofy cowboy’ against orange canyon/sand without turning into “monocolor” or “color vomit.”
key_stories.process: Kaze cycles through saturation/hue experiments, pulls reference from cartoons/AI concept art, and then tests a skybox change that immediately improves the perceived cohesion; he then revisits fog color options in that new lighting context.
key_stories.outcome: He concludes the visual direction is viable enough to proceed to the next pipeline step (overhead MS Paint planning) rather than continuing to micro-tweak building colors in isolation.
key_stories.key_quote: This changes the vibe so much… We should have done the sky first.

key_stories.title: Fog looks right, but threatens performance
key_stories.summary: The aesthetic Kaze likes (fog + canyon town vibe) comes with a known technical cost on the N64 rendering pipeline. He recognizes a repeat of earlier performance pain (Oily Boily Bay) and weighs accepting a 2-cycle material hit for the sake of atmosphere.
key_stories.challenge: Implementing global fog in a way that looks good without tanking performance or forcing undesirable material setups.
key_stories.process: Kaze attempts to set fog via a dedicated ‘fog triangle/material’ approach, tests blue vs orange fog, and notes the implication that “everything” becomes 2-cycle; he solicits alternatives but doesn’t see an easy solution in the moment.
key_stories.outcome: Fog is tentatively kept because it materially improves the vibe, but it becomes a known risk item for later optimization/compromise.
key_stories.key_quote: It might just look so good that we have to take the loss.

open_questions.topic: Fog implementation vs performance tradeoff in Course 12
open_questions.context: Kaze likes the fog visually but believes it forces 2-cycle materials and could worsen performance; he references Oily Boily Bay as precedent and seems unsure if there’s a better approach within his current setup (Fast64/global fog, combiner constraints).
questions: What exact performance problems did fog cause in Oily Boily Bay (FPS drops, RSP/RDP time, overdraw), and how did you measure/feel them during playtesting?
Did you later find a workaround for fog in Course 12 (selective fogging, different combiners, per-area fog, distance culling tricks), or did you accept the 2-cycle cost?
At what point do you decide “the vibe is worth it” even if it costs performance—and who on the team influences that call (you, Biobak, testers)?

open_questions.topic: Train presence: traversal tool vs set-dressing vs platforming space
open_questions.context: Kaze wants the train to feel ever-present (visible overhead at spawn, fast travel between areas, potentially sky tracks for platforming), but also worries about boring tunnels and the weirdness of floating tracks.
questions: How did you ultimately make the train feel central to gameplay rather than just a shortcut—did it become a moving hazard, a platforming route, or mainly a transport system?
Did you end up with one continuous loop train, multiple trains, or ‘implied’ offscreen connections for performance/culling reasons?
What was the final solution for making train-track traversal fun without breaking believability (and without derailing the train conceptually)?

open_questions.topic: Mission pacing and ‘no story’ philosophy for the cowboy course
open_questions.context: Kaze rejects adding time-of-day progression or a story arc for this level, framing it as “disconnected missions,” yet he also wants early roleplay clarity (spawn facing jail, sheriff assigns tasks).
questions: Where do you draw the line between ‘light roleplay framing’ (sheriff/jail/outlaws) and a full story-driven level structure—and why did you avoid story progression here?
How did you ensure players understand each ‘case’ without turning it into slow dialogue-heavy missions that clash with Mario 64 pacing?
Did the scavenger-hunt act in Area 2 become the experiment ground for more open-ended objectives, and how did you keep it readable?
